1.verse: A Summary of Jeremiah’s Preaching - This is the message that came to Jeremiah concerning all the people of Judah. It came in the fourth year that Jehoiakim son of Josiah was king of Judah and the first year Nebuchadnezzar was king of Babylon.

2.verse: This is the message Jeremiah the prophet spoke to all the people of Judah and Jerusalem:

3.verse: The LORD has spoken his word to me again and again for these past twenty-three years. I have been a prophet since the thirteenth year of Josiah son of Amon king of Judah. I have spoken messages from the LORD to you from that time until today, but you have not listened.

4.verse: The LORD has sent all his servants the prophets [7:25; 2 Kin. 17:13] to you over and over again, but you have not listened or ·paid any attention [inclined/bent your ear] to them.

5.verse: Those prophets have said, “·Stop [Turn from/Repent of] your evil ways. ·Stop doing [Turn from/Repent of] what is wrong so you can stay in the land that the LORD gave to you and your ·ancestors [fathers] to live in forever.

6.verse: Don’t ·follow [go after] other gods to serve them or to ·worship [bow down to] them. Don’t make me, the LORD, angry by the work of your own hands [idols], or I will ·punish [harm] you.”

7.verse: “But you [people of Judah] did not listen to me,” says the LORD. “You made me angry by the work of your own hands [idols], so I ·punished [harmed] you.”

8.verse: So this is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts] says: “Since you have not listened to my messages,

9.verse: I will send for all the ·peoples [clans; families] of the north [Babylon],” says the LORD, “along with my servant Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon. I will bring them all against Judah, those who live there, and all the nations around you, too. I will ·completely destroy [annihilate] all those countries and leave them ·in ruins [desolate] forever. ·People will be shocked when they see how badly I have destroyed those countries [I will make them a horror and a hissing and an everlasting reproach].

10.verse: I will ·bring an end to [banish; cause to perish] the sounds of joy and happiness, the sounds of brides and bridegrooms [7:34; 16:9], and the sound of ·people grinding meal [the millstone]. And I will take away the light of the lamp.

11.verse: That whole ·area [land] will be an ·empty desert [ruin and desolate], and these nations will ·be slaves of [serve] the king of Babylon [Nebuchadnezzar] for seventy years [the exile].

12.verse: “But when the seventy years ·have passed [are completed], I will punish the king of Babylon and his entire nation, the land of the Chaldeans, for their ·evil [iniquity],” says the LORD. “I will make that land a ·desert [desolation] forever.

13.verse: I will ·make happen [bring on this land] all the ·terrible things [words] I said about it [Babylonia]—everything Jeremiah prophesied about all those foreign nations, the warnings written in this book [chs. 46–51].

14.verse: Even they [Babylonians] will have to serve many nations and many great kings. I will ·give them the punishment they deserve for all their own hands have done [repay them according to their deeds and according to the work of their hands].”

15.verse: Judgment on the Nations - The LORD, the God of Israel, said this to me: “Take the cup of the wine of my wrath [49:12; 51:7] from my hand and make all the nations, to whom I am sending you, drink from this cup.

16.verse: They will drink and ·stumble about [stagger; or vomit] and act like madmen because of the ·war [sword] I am going to send among them.”

17.verse: So I took the cup from the LORD’s hand and went to those nations where he sent me and made them drink from it.

18.verse: I served this wine to the people of Jerusalem and the towns of Judah, and the kings and officers of Judah, so they would become a ruin. Then people would be shocked and would ·insult them [hiss] and ·speak evil of [curse] them. And so it has been to this day.

19.verse: I also made these people drink of the LORD’s anger: Pharaoh the king of Egypt, his servants, his officers, all his people,

20.verse: and all the ·foreigners there [mixed crowd]; all the kings of the land of Uz; all the kings of the Philistines (the kings of the cities of Ashkelon, Gaza, Ekron, and the people left at Ashdod);

21.verse: the people of Edom, Moab, and ·Ammon [the sons of Ammon];

22.verse: all the kings of Tyre and Sidon; all the kings of the coastal countries ·to the west [or across the sea];

23.verse: the people of Dedan and Tema and Buz; all who ·cut their hair short [shave their temples; Deut. 14:1];

24.verse: all the kings of Arabia; and the kings of the ·people [mixed crowd] who live in the ·desert [wilderness];

25.verse: all the kings of Zimri, Elam, and Media;

26.verse: and all the kings of the north, near and far, one after the other. I made all the kingdoms on earth drink [from the cup of wrath] of the LORD’s anger, but the king of ·Babylon [Sheshak; a coded reference to Babylon] will drink from this cup after all the others.

27.verse: “Then say to them, ‘This is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: Drink ·this cup [of my anger]. Get drunk from it and vomit. Fall down and don’t get up because of the ·war [sword] I am sending among you!’

28.verse: “If they refuse to take the cup from your hand and drink, say to them, ‘The LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts] says this: You must drink [from this cup].

29.verse: Look! I am ·already bringing [beginning to bring] ·disaster [harm; trouble] on this city that is called by my name [Jerusalem]. Do you think you will not be punished? You will ·be punished [not go unpunished]! I am ·sending [calling for] ·war [a sword] on all the people of the earth, says the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts].’

30.verse: “You [Jeremiah] will prophesy against them with all these words. Say to them: ‘The LORD will roar [like a lion] from heaven [Amos 1:2] and will ·shout [give forth] from his holy lair [the Temple]. He will roar loudly against his ·land [sheepfold]. He will shout like people who walk on grapes [Is. 63:2–6; Rev. 19:15]; he will shout against all who live on the earth.

31.verse: The ·noise [clamor] will spread all over the earth, because the LORD will accuse all the nations. He will ·judge and tell what is wrong with [bring an indictment against] all ·people [flesh], and he will kill the evil people with a sword,’” says the LORD.

32.verse: This is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts] says: “Disasters will soon ·spread [go out] from nation to nation. They will come like a powerful storm from the faraway places on earth.”

33.verse: At that time those killed by the LORD will reach from one end of the earth to the other. No one will ·cry [mourn] for them or gather up their bodies and bury them. They will be left lying on the ground like dung [8:2; 9:22; 16:4].

34.verse: Cry, you ·leaders [shepherds]! Cry out loud! Roll around in the ·dust [ashes], ·leaders of the people [nobles of the flock]! ·It is now time for you to be killed [Your days are filled for slaughter]. You will fall and be scattered, like ·pieces of a broken [a choice/precious] jar.

35.verse: There will be no place for the ·leaders [shepherds] to ·hide [flee]; ·they [the nobles of the flock] will not escape.

36.verse: I hear the sound of the ·leaders [shepherds] shouting. I hear the ·leaders of the people [nobles of the flock] crying loudly, because the LORD is destroying their ·land [pastureland].

37.verse: Those peaceful pastures will be ·like an empty desert [devastated], because the LORD is very angry.

38.verse: Like a lion, he has left his den. Their land has been ·destroyed [desolated] because of the terrible ·war [sword] he brought, because of his fierce anger.

1.verse: Jeremiah’s Lesson at the Temple - This message came from the LORD ·soon after Jehoiakim son of Josiah became [at the beginning of the reign of Jehoiakim] king of Judah [ruled 605–597 BC].

2.verse: This is what the LORD said: “Jeremiah, stand in the courtyard of the ·Temple [house] of the LORD. ·Give this message [Say] to all the people of the towns of Judah who are coming to ·worship [bow down] at the ·Temple [house] of the LORD. Tell them everything I tell you to say; don’t leave out a word.

3.verse: Maybe they will listen and ·stop [return/repent from] their evil ways. If they will, I will ·change my mind [relent] about bringing on them the ·disaster [evil; trouble] that I am planning because of the evil they have done.

4.verse: Say to them: ‘This is what the LORD says: You must ·obey [listen to] me and follow my ·teachings [instructions; laws] that I gave you.

5.verse: You must listen to what my servants the prophets [25:4] say to you. I have sent them to you again and again, but you did not ·listen [obey].

6.verse: If you don’t obey me, I will ·destroy my Temple in Jerusalem as I destroyed my Holy Tent at [make this house like] Shiloh [7:12–14; 1 Sam. 4:1–22; Ps. 78:60–64]. When I do, ·people all over the world will curse Jerusalem [I will make this city a curse].’”

7.verse: The priests, the prophets, and all the people heard Jeremiah speaking these words in the ·Temple [house] of the LORD.

8.verse: When Jeremiah finished speaking ·everything [all the words] the LORD had commanded him to say, the priests, prophets, and all the people ·grabbed [seized] Jeremiah. They said, “You must die!

9.verse: ·How dare [Why do…?] you prophesy in the name of the LORD that this ·Temple [house] will be like the one at Shiloh [destroyed]! ·How dare [Why do…?] you say that this city [Jerusalem] will become a ·desert [ruin] without anyone to live in it!” And all the people ·crowded [assembled] around Jeremiah in the ·Temple [house] of the LORD.

10.verse: Now when the officers of Judah heard ·about what was happening [these things/words], they came out of the king’s ·palace [house] and went up to the ·Temple [house] of the LORD and took their places at the entrance of the New Gate.

11.verse: Then the priests and prophets said to the officers and all the other people, “·Jeremiah [This man] ·should be killed [deserves the death sentence]. He prophesied against this city [Jerusalem], and you heard him ·yourselves [with your ears].”

12.verse: Then Jeremiah spoke these words to all the officers of Judah and all the other people: “The LORD sent me to ·say [prophesy] ·everything [all these words] you have heard about this ·Temple [house] and this city.

13.verse: Now ·change [improve; mend] your ·lives and start doing good [ways and your deeds] and ·obey [listen to the voice of] the LORD your God. Then he will ·change his mind and not bring on you [relent of] the ·disaster [evil; trouble] he has told you about.

14.verse: As for me, I am in your ·power [hand]. Do to me what you think is good and right in your eyes.

15.verse: But be sure of one thing. If you kill me, you will be ·guilty of killing an innocent person [placing innocent blood on yourselves; Ex. 23:7; Deut. 19:10, 13]. ·You will make this city and everyone who lives in it guilty, too […and on this city and everyone who lives in it]! The LORD truly sent me to ·you to give you this message [speak this word in your ears].”

16.verse: Then the officers and all the people said to the priests and the prophets, “·Jeremiah must not be killed [This man does not deserve the death penalty]. ·What he told us comes from [He has spoken to us in the name of] the LORD our God.”

17.verse: Then some of the elders of the land [of Judah] stood up and said to all the people,

18.verse: “Micah, from the city of Moresheth [Micah 1:1, 14], was a prophet during the ·time Hezekiah was [days of Hezekiah] king of Judah. Micah said to all the people of Judah, ‘This is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts] says: ·Jerusalem [Zion; the location of the Temple] will be plowed like a field. ·It [Jerusalem] will become a ·pile of rocks [a heap of ruins], and the ·hill [mountain] where the ·Temple [house] stands will be ·covered with bushes [a forested high place; Mic. 3:12].’

19.verse: “·Hezekiah king of Judah and the people of Judah did not [Did Hezekiah king of Judah and people of Judah try to…?] kill Micah. ·You know [Do you not know…?] that Hezekiah feared the LORD [Prov. 1:7] and ·tried to please [sought the favor of] the LORD. So the LORD ·changed his mind [relented] and did not bring on Judah the ·disaster [evil; harm] he had promised. We will bring a terrible ·disaster [evil; harm] on ourselves [by hurting Jeremiah]!”

20.verse: (Now there was another man who prophesied in the name of the LORD. His name was Uriah son of Shemaiah from the city of Kiriath Jearim. He ·preached [prophesied] the same things against this city [Jerusalem] and this land [Judah] that Jeremiah did.

21.verse: When King Jehoiakim, all his army officers, and all the leaders of Judah heard ·Uriah preach [his words], King Jehoiakim ·wanted [sought] to kill Uriah. But Uriah heard about it and was afraid. So he escaped to Egypt.

22.verse: Then King Jehoiakim sent Elnathan son of Acbor and some other men to Egypt,

23.verse: and they brought Uriah back from Egypt. Then they took him to King Jehoiakim, who had Uriah ·killed [struck] with a sword. His body was thrown into the burial place where ·poor [common] people are buried.)

24.verse: ·Ahikam son of Shaphan supported [The hand of Ahikam son of Shaphan was with] Jeremiah [2 Kin. 22:3, 8–10]. So Ahikam did not hand Jeremiah over to be killed by the people.

1.verse: Nebuchadnezzar Is Made Ruler - The LORD spoke his word to Jeremiah soon after ·Zedekiah [or Jehoiakim] son of Josiah was made king of Judah.

2.verse: This is what the LORD said to me: “Make a yoke out of straps and poles, and put it on the back of your neck.

3.verse: Then send messages to the kings of Edom, Moab, ·Ammon [the sons of Ammon], Tyre, and Sidon by their messengers who have come to Jerusalem to see Zedekiah king of Judah.

4.verse: Tell them to give this message to their masters: ‘The LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: “Tell your masters:

5.verse: I made the earth, its people, and all its animals with my great power and ·strength [outstretched hand]. I can give the earth to anyone ·I want [that is right in my eyes].

6.verse: Now I have given all these lands to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, my servant. I will make even the wild animals ·obey [serve] him.

7.verse: All nations will serve Nebuchadnezzar and his son and grandson. Then the time will come for Babylon to be defeated, and many nations and great kings will make Babylon their ·servant [or slave].

8.verse: “‘ “But if some nations or kingdoms refuse to serve Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and refuse to ·be under his control [put their necks under the yoke of the king of Babylon], I will punish them with ·war [the sword], ·hunger [famine], and ·terrible diseases [plague; pestilence], says the LORD. ·I will use Nebuchadnezzar to destroy them […until I have completed its destruction by its hand].

9.verse: So don’t listen to your prophets, ·those who use magic to tell the future [your diviners], ·those who explain dreams [your dreamers], the mediums, or magicians. They all tell you, ‘·You will not be slaves to [Do not serve] the king of Babylon.’

10.verse: They are ·telling [prophesying to] you lies that will cause you to be taken far from your homeland. I will ·force you to leave [drive you from] your homes, and you will ·die in another land [perish].

11.verse: But the nations who ·put themselves under the control [bring their necks under the yoke] of the king of Babylon and serve him I will let stay in their own country, says the LORD. The people from those nations will live in their own land and farm it.”’”

12.verse: I gave the same message to Zedekiah king of Judah. I said, “Put yourself under the ·control [yoke] of the king of Babylon and serve him, and you will live.

13.verse: Why should you and your people die from ·war [sword], ·hunger [famine], or ·disease [pestilence], as the LORD said would happen to those who do not serve the king of Babylon?

14.verse: But the prophets [false prophets] are saying, ‘You will ·never be slaves to [not serve] the king of Babylon.’ Don’t listen to them because they are prophesying lies to you!

15.verse: ‘I did not send them,’ says the LORD. ‘They are prophesying lies ·and saying the message is from me [in my name]. So I will ·send you away [drive you out; said to Judah]. And you and those prophets who prophesy to you will ·die [perish; Deut. 18:21–22].’”

16.verse: Then I [Jeremiah] said to the priests and all this people, “This is what the LORD says: Those false prophets are saying, ‘The ·Babylonians will soon return what they took from the Temple of the LORD [vessels of the house of the LORD will be returned from Babylon; 2 Kin. 24:13; Dan. 1:2].’ Don’t listen to them! They are prophesying lies to you.

17.verse: Don’t listen to those prophets. But serve the king of Babylon, and you will live. ·There is no reason for you to cause Jerusalem to [Why should this city…?] become a ruin.

18.verse: If they are prophets and have the ·message from [word of] the LORD, let them ·pray to [intercede with] the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts]. Let them ask that the ·items [vessels] which ·are still [remain] in the ·Temple [house] of the LORD and in the king’s ·palace [house] and in Jerusalem not ·be taken away [go] to Babylon.

19.verse: “This is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts] says about those ·items [vessels] left in this city [Jerusalem]: the pillars [1 Kin. 7:15–22], the Sea [1 Kin. 7:23–26], the stands [1 Kin. 7:27–37] and other things [bronze basins, various altars, lampstands, and more].

20.verse: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon did not take these away when he ·took as captives [exiled] Jehoiachin [Jeconiah] son of Jehoiakim king of Judah and all the ·other important people [nobles] from Judah and Jerusalem to Babylon.

21.verse: This is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says about the ·items [vessels] left in the ·Temple [house] of the LORD and in the king’s ·palace [house] and in Jerusalem:

22.verse: ‘·All of them will also be taken [They will be brought] to Babylon. And they will stay there until the day I ·go to get [attend to] them,’ says the LORD. ‘Then I will bring them back and return them to this place.’”

1.verse: The False Prophet Hananiah - It was in that same year, in the fifth month of Zedekiah’s fourth year as king of Judah [593 BC], soon after he began to rule. The prophet Hananiah son of Azzur, from the town of Gibeon, spoke to me in the ·Temple [house] of the LORD ·in front [before the eyes] of the priests and all the people. He said:

2.verse: “The LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: ‘I have broken the yoke of the king of Babylon.

3.verse: Before two years are over, I will ·bring back [restore] ·everything [all the vessels] that Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon took to Babylon from the LORD’s ·Temple [house].

4.verse: I will also ·bring back [restore] ·Jehoiachin [Jeconiah] son of Jehoiakim king of Judah and all the other ·captives [exiles] from Judah who went to Babylon,’ says the LORD. ‘So I will break the yoke of the king of Babylon.’”

5.verse: Then the prophet Jeremiah spoke to the prophet Hananiah ·in front [before the eyes] of the priests and all the people who were standing in the ·Temple [house] of the LORD.

6.verse: He said, “Amen! Let the LORD really do that! May the LORD ·make the message you prophesy come true [confirm your word which you prophesied]. May he ·bring back here [restore] ·everything [the vessels] the LORD’s ·Temple [house] and all the ·people who were taken as captives [exiles] to Babylon.

7.verse: “But listen to ·what I am going to say to you and [this word which I am speaking in your ears and the ears of] all the people.

8.verse: There were prophets long before we became prophets, Hananiah. They prophesied that war, ·hunger [famine; or disaster; calamity], and ·terrible diseases [plague; pestilence] would come to many countries and great kingdoms.

9.verse: But if a prophet prophesies that we will have peace and that message comes true, he can be recognized as one truly sent by the LORD [prophets usually came announcing judgment not peace].”

10.verse: Then the prophet Hananiah took the yoke off Jeremiah’s neck and ·broke [shattered] it.

11.verse: Hananiah said ·in front [before the eyes] of all the people, “This is what the LORD says: ‘In the same way I will break the yoke of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon. He put that yoke on all the nations of the world, but I will break it before two years are over.’” After Hananiah had said that, Jeremiah ·left the Temple [went on his way].

12.verse: The LORD spoke his word to Jeremiah after the prophet Hananiah had broken the yoke off of the prophet Jeremiah’s neck.

13.verse: The LORD said, “Go and tell Hananiah, ‘This is what the LORD says: You have broken a wooden yoke, but I will make a yoke of iron in its place!

14.verse: The LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: I will put a yoke of iron on the necks of all these nations to make them serve Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, and they will be slaves to him. I will even give Nebuchadnezzar ·control over the wild animals [the beasts of the field].’ ”

15.verse: Then the prophet Jeremiah said to the prophet Hananiah, “Listen, Hananiah! The LORD did not send you, and you have made the people of Judah ·trust [have confidence] in lies.

16.verse: So this is what the LORD says: ‘Soon I will ·remove you from [send you off the face of] the earth. You will die this year, because you taught ·the people to turn [rebellion] against the LORD [Deut. 18:20].’”

17.verse: Hananiah died in the seventh month of that same year.

1.verse: A Letter to the Captives in Babylon - This is the ·letter [words of the scroll] that Jeremiah the prophet sent from Jerusalem to the remaining elders who were among the ·captives [exiles], the priests, and the prophets. He sent it to all the other people Nebuchadnezzar had taken as ·captives [exiles] from Jerusalem to Babylon [in 597 BC; 2 Kin. 24:12–17; 2 Chr. 36:6–8].

2.verse: (This ·letter [scroll] was sent after all these people were taken away: Jehoiachin [Jeconiah] the king and the queen mother [Nehushta; 13:18]; the ·officers [servants; eunuchs] and leaders of Judah and Jerusalem; and the craftsmen and metalworkers from Jerusalem.)

3.verse: Zedekiah king of Judah sent Elasah son of Shaphan [perhaps the court secretary under Josiah; 2 Kin. 22:3, 8–9] and Gemariah son of Hilkiah [perhaps the high priest under Josiah; 2 Kin. 22:8] to Babylon to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon. So Jeremiah gave them this ·letter [scroll] to carry to Babylon:

5.verse: “Build houses and settle ·in the land [down]. Plant gardens and eat ·the food they grow [their fruit].

6.verse: ·Get married [Take wives] and have sons and daughters. ·Find [Take] wives for your sons, and let your daughters be married so they also may have sons and daughters. ·Have many children in Babylon [Multiply there]; don’t become fewer in number.

7.verse: ·Also do good things for [Seek the peace/security of] the city where I ·sent you as captives [exiled you]. Pray to the LORD for the city where you are living, because ·if good things happen in the city, good things will happen to you also [in its peace/security you will have peace/security].”

8.verse: The LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: “Don’t let the prophets among you and the ·people who do magic [diviners] ·fool [deceive] you. Don’t listen to ·their dreams [their/or your dreams that they/or you dream].

9.verse: They are prophesying ·lies [falsehoods] to you, ·saying that their message is from me […in my name]. But I did not send them,” says the LORD.

10.verse: This is what the LORD says: “·Babylon will be powerful for seventy years. After that time I will come to [Only after the seventy years of Babylon are filled will I visit; 25:11] you, and I will ·keep my promise [confirm my good word] to ·bring [restore] you back to ·Jerusalem [this place].

11.verse: I say this because I know ·what [the plans] I am planning for you,” says the LORD. “I have ·good plans for you [plans for your peace/security], not plans ·to hurt you [for your harm]. I will give you hope and a good future.

12.verse: Then you will call ·my name [me]. You will come to me and pray to me, and I will listen to you.

13.verse: You will search for me. And when you search for me with all your heart, you will find me [Dan. 9:4–19]!

14.verse: I will let you find me,” says the LORD. “And I will ·bring you back from your captivity [restore your fortunes]. I ·forced you to leave [drove you from] this place, but I will gather you from all the nations, from the places I have ·sent you as captives [exiled you],” says the LORD. “And I will ·bring you back [restore you] to this place.”

15.verse: You might say, “The LORD has ·given [raised up/established/confirmed for; Deut. 18:18] us prophets here in Babylon.”

16.verse: But the LORD says this about the king who is sitting on David’s throne now and all the other people still in this city [Jerusalem], your ·relatives [brothers] who did not go ·as captives to Babylon [out as exiles] with you.

17.verse: The LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts] says: “I will soon send ·war [sword], ·hunger [famine], and ·terrible diseases [plague; pestilence; against those still in Jerusalem]. I will make them like bad figs that are too rotten to eat [24:1–10].

18.verse: I will ·chase [pursue] them with ·war [sword], ·hunger [famine], and ·terrible diseases [plague; pestilence]. I will make them ·hated by [a horror to] all the kingdoms of the earth. ·People will curse them and be shocked and will use them as a shameful example […an object of cursing, shock, hissing and reproach] ·wherever I make them go [among the nations where I have driven them].

19.verse: This is because they have not listened to my message,” says the LORD. “I sent my ·message [word] to them again and again through my servants, the prophets, but they did not listen,” says the LORD.

20.verse: You ·captives [exiles], whom I ·forced to leave [sent from] Jerusalem ·and go to [to] Babylon, listen to the message from the LORD.

21.verse: The LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says this about Ahab son of Kolaiah and Zedekiah son of Maaseiah: “These two men have been prophesying ·lies [falsehood] to you, ·saying that their message is from me [in my name]. But soon I will ·hand over those two prophets to [give them into the hand of] Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, and he will ·kill [strike] them ·in front of you [before your eyes].

22.verse: Because of them, all the ·captives [exiles] from Judah in Babylon will use this curse: ‘May the LORD ·treat [make] you like Zedekiah and Ahab, whom the king of Babylon ·burned [roasted] in the fire.’

23.verse: They have done evil things among the people of Israel. They are guilty of adultery with their neighbors’ wives. They have also spoken ·lies and said those lies were a message from me [falsehoods in my name; Deut. 18:14–21]. I did not ·tell [command] them to do that. I know what they have done; I am a witness to it,” says the LORD.

3.verse: ‘Pray [Call] to me, and I will answer you. I will tell you ·important secrets [great and hidden things] you have never ·heard [known] before.’
