5.verse: ‘Some people will come to fight against the ·Babylonians [Chaldeans]. They will fill them [the houses] with ·the bodies of people [corpses] I ·killed [struck] in my ·hot anger [anger and my wrath]. I have ·turned away [hidden my face] from this city because of all the evil its people have done.

6.verse: “‘But then I will bring ·health [recovery] and healing to the people there. I will heal them and ·let them enjoy [reveal to them] ·great [an abundance of] peace and ·safety [security].

7.verse: I will ·bring Judah and Israel back from captivity [restore the fortunes of Judah and Israel] and ·make them strong countries [rebuild them] as in the past.

8.verse: They sinned against me, but I will ·wash away [cleanse them from] that sin. They did ·evil [iniquity] and ·turned away from [transgressed against] me, but I will forgive them.

9.verse: Then it [Jerusalem] will be to me a name that brings joy! And people from all nations of the earth will praise [and glorify] it when they hear about the good things I am doing there. They will ·be surprised [fear] and ·shocked [tremble] at all the good things and the ·peace [or prosperity] I will bring to it.’

10.verse: “You are saying, ‘Our country is an ·empty desert [ruin], without people or animals.’ But this is what the LORD says: It is now quiet in the streets of Jerusalem and in the towns of Judah, without people or animals, but ·it will be noisy there soon [there will once more be heard…]!

11.verse: ·There will be […the] sounds of joy and gladness and the happy sounds of brides and bridegrooms. There will be the sounds of people bringing to the ·Temple [house] of the LORD their offerings of thanks to the LORD. They will say, ‘Praise the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], because the LORD is good! His ·love [loyalty] continues forever!’ They will say this because I will ·again do good things for Judah [restore the fortunes of the land], as I did in the beginning,” says the LORD.

12.verse: This is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts] says: “This place is ·empty [a ruin] now, without people or animals. But there will be shepherds in this place [Judah] and pastures where they let their flocks rest.

13.verse: ·Shepherds will again count their sheep as the sheep walk in front of them [Flocks will again pass under the hand of those who count them]. They will count them in the mountains and in the ·western hills [Shephelah], in ·southern Judah [the Negev] and the land of Benjamin, and around Jerusalem and the other towns of Judah!” says the LORD.

14.verse: The Good Branch - The LORD says, “The ·time is [days are] coming when I will do the good thing I promised to the people of Israel and Judah.

15.verse: In those days and at that time, I will make a ·good [righteous] branch sprout from David’s family [Is. 11:1; Zech. 3:8; 6:12]. He will do ·what is fair [justice] and ·right [righteousness] in the land.

16.verse: ·At that time [In those days] Judah will be ·saved [rescued], and the people of Jerusalem will live ·in safety [with confidence]. ·The branch will be named [This one will be called by this]: The LORD ·Does What Is Right [Our Righteousness].”

17.verse: This is what the LORD says: “·Someone from David’s family will always sit on the throne of the family [David will never lack a man who will sit on the throne of the house] of Israel [2 Sam. 7:11–16].

18.verse: And there will always be priests from the family of Levi. They will always stand before me to offer burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] and grain [gift; tribute] offerings [Lev. 2:1] and sacrifices to me [Num. 25:13].”

19.verse: The LORD spoke his word to Jeremiah, saying:

20.verse: “This is what the LORD says: I have an ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with day and night that they will always come at the right times [the covenant with Noah; Gen. 9:8–17]. If you could ·change [break] that ·agreement [covenant; treaty],

21.verse: only then could you ·change [break] my ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with David and Levi. Only then would my servant David not have a descendant ruling on his throne. And only then would the family of Levi not be serving me [in the Temple].

22.verse: But I will give many ·descendants [seed] to my servant David and to the family group of Levi who serve me. They will be as many as the stars in the sky that no one can count. They will be as many as the grains of sand on the seashore that no one can measure [Gen. 15:5; 22:17; 26:4].”

23.verse: The LORD spoke his word to Jeremiah, saying:

24.verse: “Have you [Jeremiah] heard what the people are saying? They say: ‘The LORD ·turned away from [rejected] the two ·families [kingdoms; of Israel and Judah] that he chose.’ Now they [hold my people in such contempt that they] don’t think of them as a nation anymore!”

25.verse: This is what the LORD says: “If I had not made my ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with day and night [v. 20], and if I had not made the ·laws [statutes; ordinances; requirements] for the ·sky [heavens] and earth,

26.verse: only then would I ·turn away from [reject] Jacob’s ·descendants [seed]. And only then would I not let the ·descendants [seed] of David my servant rule over the ·descendants [seed] of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. But I will be ·kind [compassionate] to them and ·cause good things to happen to them [restore their fortunes] again.”

1.verse: A Warning to Zedekiah - The LORD spoke his word to Jeremiah when Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon was fighting against Jerusalem and all the towns around it. Nebuchadnezzar had with him all his army and the armies of all the kingdoms and peoples ·he ruled [under his hand].

2.verse: This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, said: “Jeremiah, go to Zedekiah king of Judah and tell him: ‘This is what the LORD says: I will soon hand this city [Jerusalem] over to the king of Babylon, and he will burn it ·down [with fire]!

3.verse: You will not escape from ·the king of Babylon [his hand]; you will surely be captured and handed over to him. You will see the king of Babylon ·with your own eyes [eye to eye], and he will talk to you face to face. And you will go to Babylon.

4.verse: But, Zedekiah king of Judah, listen to the promise of the LORD. This is what the LORD says about you: You will not be killed with a sword.

5.verse: You will die in a peaceful way. As people ·made funeral fires [or burn spices; burn] to honor your ·ancestors [fathers], the kings who ruled before you, so people will ·make a funeral fire [or burn spices; burn] to honor you. They will ·cry for you and sadly [mourn for you and] say, “Ah, master!” I myself make this promise to you, says the LORD [52:8–11].’”

6.verse: So Jeremiah the prophet gave this message to Zedekiah in Jerusalem.

7.verse: This was while the army of the king of Babylon was fighting against Jerusalem and the cities of Judah that ·had not yet been taken [remained]—Lachish and Azekah [fortress cities to the west of Jerusalem]. These were the only ·strong, walled [fortified] cities left in the land of Judah.

8.verse: Slaves Are Mistreated - The LORD spoke his word to Jeremiah. This was after King Zedekiah had ·made [cut] an ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with all the people in Jerusalem to ·free all the Hebrew slaves [proclaim liberty/emancipation; Ex. 21:1–11; Lev. 25:39–46; Deut. 15:12–18].

9.verse: Everyone was supposed to free his Hebrew slaves, both male and female. No one was to keep a fellow ·Jew [Judean] as a slave.

10.verse: All the officers and all the people ·accepted [obeyed] this agreement; they agreed to free their male and female slaves and no longer keep them as slaves. So all the slaves were set free.

11.verse: But after that, they [the people who owned slaves] ·changed their minds [turned back]. So they took back the people they had set free and made them slaves again.

12.verse: Then the LORD spoke his word to Jeremiah:

13.verse: “This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: I brought your ·ancestors [fathers] out of Egypt ·where they were slaves [the house of bondage/slavery] and ·made [cut] an ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with them.

14.verse: I said to your ·ancestors [fathers]: ‘At the end of every seven years, each one of you must set his Hebrew slaves free. If a fellow Hebrew has sold himself to you, you must let him go free after he has served you for six years.’ But your ·ancestors [fathers] did not listen or ·pay attention [incline their ear] to me.

15.verse: A short time ago you ·changed your hearts [repented] and did what ·I say is right [was right in my eyes]. ·Each of you gave freedom […to proclaim liberty/emancipation] to his fellow Hebrews who were slaves. And you even ·made [cut] an ·agreement [covenant; treaty] before me in the place ·where I have chosen to be worshiped [called by my name].

16.verse: But now you have ·changed your minds [turned around]. You have ·shown you do not honor [profaned; dishonored] me. Each of you has taken back the male and female slaves you had set free, and you have forced them to become your slaves again.

17.verse: “So this is what the LORD says: You have not ·obeyed [listened to] me. You have not ·given freedom [proclaimed liberty/emancipation] to your fellow Hebrews, neither ·relatives [brothers] nor ·friends [neighbors]. But now I will ·give freedom [proclaim liberty/emancipation to you], says the LORD, to ·war [the sword], to ·terrible diseases [plague; pestilence], and to ·hunger [famine]. I will make you ·hated by [a horror to] all the kingdoms of the earth.

18.verse: I will hand over the men who ·broke [transgressed] my ·agreement [covenant; treaty], who have not kept the ·promises [terms of the covenant/treaty] they made before me. They cut a calf into two pieces before me and ·walked between [passed through] the pieces [an ancient oath ritual saying that if one broke the agreement they would die like the calf; Gen. 15:9–20].

19.verse: These people made the ·agreement [covenant; treaty] before me by ·walking between [passing through] the pieces of the calf: the leaders of Judah and Jerusalem, the ·officers of the court [or eunuchs], the priests, and all the people of the land.

20.verse: So I will hand them over to their enemies and to everyone who ·wants to kill them [seeks their life]. Their ·bodies [corpses] will become food for the birds of the ·air [heavens] and for the wild animals of the earth.

21.verse: I will hand Zedekiah king of Judah and his officers over to their enemies, and to everyone who ·wants to kill them [seeks their life], and to the army of the king of Babylon, even though they have ·left Jerusalem [gone up from you].

22.verse: I will give the order, says the LORD, to ·bring the Babylonian army back to Jerusalem [return them to this city]. It will fight against it, capture it, set it on fire, and burn it down. I will ·destroy the towns in Judah so that they become ruins [make the towns of Judah a desolation] where no one lives!”

1.verse: The Recabite Family Obeys God - When Jehoiakim son of Josiah was king of Judah [ruled 609–597 BC], the LORD spoke his word to Jeremiah, saying:

2.verse: “Go to the ·family [house] of Recab. Invite them to come to one of the ·side rooms [chambers] of the ·Temple [house] of the LORD, and offer them wine to drink.”

3.verse: So I went to get Jaazaniah son of Jeremiah [not the prophet, but a man with the same name], the son of Habazziniah. And I gathered all of Jaazaniah’s brothers and sons and the whole ·family [house] of the Recabites together.

4.verse: Then I brought them into the ·Temple [house] of the LORD. We went into the ·room [chamber] of the sons of Hanan son of Igdaliah, who was a man of God. The ·room [chamber] was next to the one where the officers stay and above the ·room [chamber] of Maaseiah son of Shallum, the ·doorkeeper in the Temple [guard/keeper of the threshold].

5.verse: Then I put some ·bowls [pitchers] full of wine and some cups before the men of the Recabite ·family [house]. And I said to them, “Drink some wine.”

6.verse: But the Recabite men answered, “We never drink wine. Our ·ancestor [father] Jonadab son of Recab [2 Kin. 10:15–17] gave us this command: ‘You and your descendants must never drink wine.

7.verse: Also you must never build houses, ·plant [sow] seeds, or plant vineyards, or do any of those things. You must live only in tents all your days. Then you will live ·a long time [many days] in the land where you are ·wanderers [sojourners; resident aliens].’

8.verse: So we Recabites ·have obeyed everything [listened to the voice of] Jonadab our ·ancestor [father] commanded us. Neither we nor our wives, sons, or daughters ever drink wine.

9.verse: We never build houses in which to live, or own fields or vineyards, or ·plant crops [seed].

10.verse: We have lived in tents and have obeyed everything our ancestor Jonadab commanded us.

11.verse: But when Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon ·attacked Judah [came up to the land], we said to each other, ‘Come, we must enter Jerusalem ·so we can escape [from before] the ·Babylonian [Chaldean] army and the Aramean army.’ So we have stayed [lived] in Jerusalem [though they may not be living in houses, in conformity to their ancestor’s command].”

12.verse: Then the LORD spoke his word to Jeremiah:

13.verse: “This is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: Jeremiah, go and tell the men of Judah and the people of Jerusalem: ‘·You should [Can you not…?] learn a lesson and obey my message,’ says the LORD.

14.verse: ‘Jonadab son of Recab ordered his descendants not to drink wine, and that command has been obeyed. Until today they have obeyed their ·ancestor’s [father’s] command; they do not drink wine. But I, the LORD, have given you messages again and again, but you did not ·obey [listen to] me.

15.verse: I sent all my servants the prophets to you again and again, saying, “Each of you must ·stop doing evil [turn from his evil way/path]. You must change and be good. Do not ·follow [go after] other gods to serve them. If you obey me, you will live in the land I have given to you and your ·ancestors [fathers].” But you have not ·listened [inclined your ear] to me or paid attention to my message.

16.verse: The descendants of Jonadab son of Recab obeyed the commands their ancestor gave them, but the people of Judah have not obeyed me [the Recabites carefully observe the law of a human while Israel rejects divine law].’

17.verse: “So the LORD God ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: ‘I will soon bring every ·disaster [trouble; evil] I said would come to Judah and to everyone living in Jerusalem. I spoke to those people, but they refused to listen. I called out to them, but they did not answer me.’”

18.verse: Then Jeremiah said to the [house of the] Recabites, “This is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: ‘You have ·obeyed [listened to] the commands of your ·ancestor [father] Jonadab and have ·followed all of his teachings [kept/guarded all his commands]; you have done everything he commanded.’

19.verse: So this is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: ‘·There will always be a descendant of Jonadab son of Recab to serve me [Jonadab son of Recab will not lack a descendant to stand before me for all days].’”

1.verse: Jehoiakim Burns Jeremiah’s Scroll - The LORD spoke this word to Jeremiah during the fourth year that Jehoiakim son of Josiah was king of Judah [605 BC]:

2.verse: “Get a scroll. Write on it all the words I have spoken to you about Israel and Judah and all the nations. Write everything from when I first spoke to you, when Josiah was king, until now [his prophecies began in the thirteenth year of this king, 626 BC; 1:1–3].

3.verse: Maybe the ·family [house] of Judah will hear what ·disasters [evil; troubles] I am planning to ·bring on [do to] them and will ·stop doing wicked things [turn back from his evil ways/paths]. Then I would forgive them for ·the sins and the evil things they have done [their iniquities and their sins].”

4.verse: So Jeremiah called for Baruch son of Neriah [32:12; 43:3, 6; 45:1–2]. ·Jeremiah spoke the messages the LORD had given him, and Baruch wrote those messages [Baruch wrote from the mouth of Jeremiah all the words of the LORD which he spoke to him] on the scroll.

5.verse: Then Jeremiah commanded Baruch, “I cannot go to the ·Temple [house] of the LORD. I ·must stay here [am confined/restricted/imprisoned].

6.verse: So I want you to go to the ·Temple [house] of the LORD on a day when the people are fasting. Read from the scroll ·to [in the ears of] all the people of Judah who come into Jerusalem from their towns. Read the messages from the LORD, which are the words you wrote on the scroll ·as I spoke them to you [from my mouth].

7.verse: Perhaps ·they will ask the LORD to help them [their supplications will fall before the LORD]. Perhaps each one will ·stop doing wicked things [turn from their evil ways], because the LORD has announced that he is very angry with them.”

8.verse: So Baruch son of Neriah did everything Jeremiah the prophet ·told [commanded] him to do. In the LORD’s ·Temple [house] he read aloud the scroll that had the LORD’s messages written on it.

9.verse: In the ninth month of the fifth year that Jehoiakim son of Josiah was king [604 BC], a fast was announced. All the people of Jerusalem and everyone who had come into Jerusalem from the towns of Judah were supposed to ·give up eating to honor [fast before] the LORD.

10.verse: At that time Baruch read to all the people there the scroll containing Jeremiah’s words. He read the scroll in the ·Temple [house] of the LORD in the room of Gemariah son of Shaphan, a ·royal secretary [scribe]. That ·room [chamber] was in the upper courtyard at the entrance of the New Gate of the Temple.

11.verse: Micaiah son of Gemariah, the son of Shaphan, heard all the messages from the LORD that were on the scroll.

12.verse: Micaiah went down to the ·royal secretary’s [scribe’s] room in the king’s ·palace [house] where all of the officers were sitting: Elishama the ·royal secretary [scribe]; Delaiah son of Shemaiah; Elnathan son of Acbor [2 Kin. 22:8–10]; Gemariah son of Shaphan; Zedekiah son of Hananiah; and all the other officers.

13.verse: Micaiah told those officers everything he had heard Baruch read to the people from the scroll.

14.verse: Then the officers sent a man named Jehudi son of Nethaniah to Baruch. (Nethaniah was the son of Shelemiah, who was the son of Cushi.) Jehudi said to Baruch, “·Bring [Take in your hand] the scroll that you read ·to [in the ears of] the people and come with me.” So Baruch son of Neriah took in his hand the scroll and went with Jehudi to the officers.

15.verse: Then the officers said to Baruch, “Please sit down and read the scroll ·to us [in our ears].” So Baruch read the scroll ·to them [in their ears] .

16.verse: When the officers heard all the words, they became afraid and looked at each other. They said to Baruch, “We must certainly tell the king about these words.”

17.verse: Then the officers asked Baruch, “Tell us, please, ·where did you get all these words you wrote on the scroll [how did you write all these words]? ·Did you write down what Jeremiah said to you [At his dictation; From his mouth]?”

18.verse: “Yes,” Baruch answered. “Jeremiah spoke them ·all to me [from his mouth], and I wrote them down with ink on this scroll.”

19.verse: Then the officers said to Baruch, “You and Jeremiah must go and hide, and ·don’t tell anyone [no one must know] where you are.”

20.verse: The officers put the scroll in the room of Elishama the ·royal secretary [scribe]. Then they went to the king in the courtyard and told ·him all about the scroll [all these words in the ear of the king].

21.verse: So King Jehoiakim sent Jehudi to get the scroll. Jehudi brought the scroll from the room of Elishama the ·royal secretary [scribe] and read it ·to [in the ears of] the king and ·to [in the ears of] all the officers who stood around the king.

22.verse: It was the ninth month of the year [late autumn], so King Jehoiakim was sitting in the winter apartment. There was a fire burning in a ·small firepot [brazier] in front of him.

23.verse: After Jehudi had read three or four columns, ·the king [he] cut those columns off of the scroll with a penknife and threw them into the ·firepot [brazier]. Finally, the whole scroll was burned in the fire.

24.verse: King Jehoiakim and his servants heard ·everything that was said [all these words], but they were not frightened! They did not tear their clothes [to show their sorrow].

25.verse: Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah ·even tried to talk [beseeched] King Jehoiakim out of burning the scroll, but he would not listen to them.

26.verse: Instead, the king ordered Jerahmeel son of the king, Seraiah son of Azriel, and Shelemiah son of Abdeel to arrest Baruch the ·secretary [scribe] and Jeremiah the prophet. But the LORD had hidden them.

27.verse: So King Jehoiakim burned the scroll where Baruch had written ·all the words Jeremiah had spoken to him [from the mouth of Jeremiah]. Then the LORD spoke his word to Jeremiah:

28.verse: “Get another scroll. Write all the words on it that were on the first scroll that Jehoiakim king of Judah burned up.

29.verse: Also say this to Jehoiakim king of Judah: ‘This is what the LORD says: You burned up that scroll and said, “Why, Jeremiah, did you write on it ‘the king of Babylon will surely come and destroy this land and the people and animals in it’?”

30.verse: So this is what the LORD says about Jehoiakim king of Judah: Jehoiakim’s descendants will not sit on David’s throne. When Jehoiakim dies, his body will be thrown out on the ground. It will be left out in the heat of the day and in the frost of the night.

31.verse: I will punish Jehoiakim and his ·children [seed] and his servants, because ·they have done evil things [of their guilt/iniquity]. I will bring ·disasters [evil; trouble] upon them and upon all the people in Jerusalem and Judah—everything I promised but which they refused to hear.’”

32.verse: So Jeremiah took another scroll and gave it to Baruch son of Neriah, his ·secretary [scribe]. ·As Jeremiah spoke [From the mouth of Jeremiah], Baruch wrote on the scroll the same words that were on the scroll Jehoiakim king of Judah had burned in the fire. And many similar words were added to the second scroll.

1.verse: Jeremiah in Prison - Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon had ·appointed [made king] Zedekiah son of Josiah to be king of Judah [in 597 BC; he ruled until 586 BC]. Zedekiah took the place of ·Jehoiachin [Coniah] son of Jehoiakim.

2.verse: But Zedekiah, his servants, and the people of Judah did not listen to the words the LORD had spoken through Jeremiah the prophet.

3.verse: Now King Zedekiah sent Jehucal son of Shelemiah and the priest Zephaniah son of Maaseiah [21:1; 29:25, 29; 52:24] with a message to Jeremiah the prophet. This was the message: “Jeremiah, please pray to the LORD our God for us.”

4.verse: At that time Jeremiah had not yet been put into ·prison [the house of confinement]. So he ·was free to go anywhere he wanted [came and went among the people].

5.verse: The army of the ·king of Egypt [Pharaoh] had marched from Egypt [toward Judah]. Now the ·Babylonian army [Chaldeans] had ·surrounded [besieged] the city of Jerusalem. When they heard about the Egyptian army marching toward them, the Babylonian army left Jerusalem.

6.verse: The LORD spoke his word to Jeremiah the prophet:

7.verse: “This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: Jehucal and Zephaniah, I know Zedekiah king of Judah sent you to seek me [to get his help]. Tell this to King Zedekiah: ‘The army of the king of Egypt came here to help you, but they will ·go back [return] to Egypt.

8.verse: After that, the ·Babylonian army [Chaldeans] will return and ·attack [fight] this city [Jerusalem] and capture it and burn it ·down [with fire].’

9.verse: “This is what the LORD says: People of Jerusalem, do not ·fool [deceive] yourselves. Don’t say, ‘The ·Babylonian army [Chaldeans] will surely ·leave us alone [go away from us].’ They will not!

10.verse: Even if you ·defeated [struck] all of the ·Babylonian army [Chaldeans] that is ·attacking [fighting] you and there were only a few injured men left in their tents, they would ·come from their tents [rise up] and burn ·down Jerusalem [this city with fire]!”

11.verse: So the ·Babylonian [Chaldean] army left Jerusalem to fight the army of ·the king of Egypt [Pharaoh].

12.verse: Now Jeremiah tried to travel from Jerusalem to the land of Benjamin to get his share of the property ·that belonged to his family [among the people; 32:1–15].

13.verse: When Jeremiah got to the Benjamin Gate [38:7; Ezek. 48:32; Zech 14:10] of Jerusalem, the captain in charge of the guards arrested him. The captain’s name was Irijah son of Shelemiah son of Hananiah. Irijah said, “You are ·leaving us to join the Babylonians [deserting/defecting/falling to the Chaldeans]!”

14.verse: But Jeremiah said to Irijah, “·That’s not true [False; Lies]! I am not ·leaving to join the Babylonians [deserting/defecting/falling to the Chaldeans].” Irijah refused to listen to Jeremiah, so he arrested Jeremiah and took him to the officers of Jerusalem.

15.verse: Those ·rulers [officers] were very angry with Jeremiah and ·beat [struck] him. Then they put him in ·jail [house of confinement] in the house of Jonathan the ·royal secretary [scribe], which had been made into a prison [house of confinement].

16.verse: So those people put Jeremiah into a cell in a ·dungeon [house of the pit/cistern], and Jeremiah was there for ·a long time [many days].

17.verse: Then King Zedekiah sent for Jeremiah and had him brought to the palace. Zedekiah asked him in ·private [secret], “Is there any message from the LORD?” Jeremiah answered, “Yes, there is. Zedekiah, you will be handed over to the king of Babylon.”

18.verse: Then Jeremiah said to King Zedekiah, “What ·crime [sin] have I done against you or your officers or the people of Jerusalem? Why have you ·thrown [placed] me into ·prison [the house of confinement]?

19.verse: Where are your prophets that prophesied this message to you: ‘The king of Babylon will not attack you or this land’ [Judah]?

20.verse: But now, my master, king [of Judah], please listen to me, and please ·do what I ask of [let my pleas for help/supplications fall before] you. Do not send me back to the house of Jonathan the ·royal secretary [scribe], or I will die there!”

21.verse: So King Zedekiah gave orders for Jeremiah to be put under guard in the courtyard of the guard and to be given bread each day from the street of the bakers until there was no more bread in the city. So he stayed under guard in the courtyard of the guard.

1.verse: Jeremiah Is Thrown into a Well - Shephatiah son of Mattan, Gedaliah son of Pashhur, ·Jehucal [Jucal; 37:3] son of Shelemiah, and Pashhur son of Malkijah [21:1] heard what Jeremiah was telling all the people. He said:

2.verse: “This is what the LORD says: ‘Everyone who stays in this city [Jerusalem] will die ·from war [by sword], or ·hunger [famine], or ·terrible diseases [plague; pestilence]. But everyone who ·surrenders [goes out] to the ·Babylonian army [Chaldeans] will live; ·they will escape with their lives and [their lives will be plunder and they will] live.’

3.verse: And this is what the LORD says: ‘This city will surely be handed over to the army of the king of Babylon. He will capture this city!’”

4.verse: Then the officers said to the king, “This man [Jeremiah] must be put to death! He is ·discouraging [demoralizing; weakening the hands of] the soldiers who are still in the city, and all the people, by what he is saying to them. He ·does not want good to happen to us [is not seeking our welfare/peace]; ·he wants to ruin us […only harm/trouble/evil].”

5.verse: King Zedekiah said to them, “·Jeremiah is in your control [He is in your hands]. ·I cannot do anything [The king is powerless] to stop you.”

6.verse: So they [the officers] took Jeremiah and put him into the ·well [cistern; pit] of Malkijah, the king’s son, which was in the courtyard of the guards. The officers used ropes to lower Jeremiah into the ·well [cistern; pit], which did not have any water in it, only mud. And Jeremiah sank down into the mud.

7.verse: But Ebed-Melech, a Cushite [an Ethiopian] and a ·servant [or eunuch] in the ·palace [house of the king], heard that the officers had put Jeremiah into the ·well [cistern; pit]. As King Zedekiah was sitting at the Benjamin Gate,

8.verse: Ebed-Melech left the ·palace [house of the king] and went to the king. Ebed-Melech said to him,

9.verse: “My master and king, these rulers have acted in an evil way. They have treated Jeremiah the prophet badly. They have thrown him into a ·well [cistern; pit] and left him there to die! ·When there [or There] is no more bread in the city, he will starve to death.”

10.verse: Then King Zedekiah commanded Ebed-Melech the Cushite, “Take thirty men from the palace and lift Jeremiah the prophet out of the ·well [cistern; pit] before he dies.”

11.verse: So Ebed-Melech took the men with him and went to a room under the storeroom in the palace. He took some ·old rags [tattered] and worn-out clothes from that room. Then he let those rags down with some ropes to Jeremiah in the ·well [cistern; well].

12.verse: Ebed-Melech the Cushite said to Jeremiah, “Put these ·old rags [tattered] and worn-out clothes under your arms to be pads for the ropes.” So Jeremiah did as Ebed-Melech said.

13.verse: The men pulled Jeremiah up with the ropes and lifted him out of the ·well [cistern; pit; Ps. 30:1–3]. And Jeremiah stayed under guard in the courtyard of the guard [39:15–18].

14.verse: Zedekiah Questions Jeremiah - Then King Zedekiah sent someone to get Jeremiah the prophet and bring him to the third entrance to the ·Temple [house] of the LORD. The king said to Jeremiah, “I am going to ask you something. Do not hide anything from me, but tell me everything honestly [37:16–21].”

15.verse: Jeremiah said to Zedekiah, “If I give you an answer, ·you will surely [won’t you…?] kill me. And even if I give you advice, you will not listen to me.”

16.verse: But King Zedekiah ·made a secret promise [swore in secret] to Jeremiah, “As surely as the LORD lives who has given us breath and life, I will not kill you. And I promise not to hand you over to these men [the officers] who ·want to kill you [seek your life].”

17.verse: Then Jeremiah said to Zedekiah, “This is what the LORD God ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: ‘If you ·surrender [go out] to the officers of the king of Babylon, your life will be saved. This city [Jerusalem] will not be burned ·down [with fire], and you and your ·family [house] will live.

18.verse: But if you refuse to ·surrender [go out] to the officers of the king of Babylon, this city will be handed over to the ·Babylonian army [Chaldeans], and they will burn it ·down [with fire]. And you yourself will not escape from ·them [their hand].’”

19.verse: Then King Zedekiah said to Jeremiah, “I’m afraid of some ·Jews [Judeans] who have already ·gone over to the side of [deserted/defected/fallen to] the ·Babylonian army [Chaldeans]. If they [the Babylonians] hand me over to them, they will ·treat me badly [abuse me].”

20.verse: But Jeremiah answered, “·The Babylonians will not hand you over to the Jews [You will not be given up]. ·Obey [Listen to the voice of] the LORD by doing what I tell you. Then things will go well for you, and your life will be saved.

21.verse: But if you refuse to ·surrender [go out] to the Babylonians, the LORD has shown me what will happen.

22.verse: All the women left in the ·palace [house] of the king of Judah will be brought out and taken to the important officers of the king of Babylon. Your women will ·make fun of you with this song [say]: ‘Your good friends ·misled [deceived; seduced; enticed] you and ·were stronger than [overpowered] you. While your feet ·were stuck [sank down] in the mud, they ·left [turned their back on] you.’

23.verse: “All your wives and children will be brought out and given to the Babylonian army. You yourself will not even escape from them. You will be ·taken prisoner [captured] by the king of Babylon, and this city [Jerusalem] will be burned ·down [with fire].”

24.verse: Then Zedekiah said to Jeremiah, “Do not tell anyone that I have been talking to you, or you will die.

25.verse: If the officers find out I talked to you, they will come to you and say, ‘Tell us what you said to King Zedekiah and what he said to you. Don’t ·keep any secrets from us [conceal anything from us]. If you don’t tell us everything, we will kill you.’

26.verse: If they ask you, tell them, ‘I was ·begging [making my pleas for help/supplications/falling before] the king not to ·send [return] me back to Jonathan’s house to die.’”

27.verse: All the officers did come to question Jeremiah. So he told them everything the king had ordered him to say. Then the officers said no more to Jeremiah, because no one had heard what Jeremiah and the king had discussed.

28.verse: So Jeremiah stayed under guard in the courtyard of the guard until the day Jerusalem was captured.

1.verse: The Fall of Jerusalem - This is how Jerusalem was captured: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon marched against Jerusalem with his whole army and ·surrounded the city to attack it [besieged it]. This was during the tenth month of the ninth year Zedekiah was king of Judah [January 588 BC; 52:4].

2.verse: This lasted until the ninth day of the fourth month in Zedekiah’s eleventh year [July 18, 586 BC]. Then the city wall was ·broken through [breached].

3.verse: And all these officers of the king of Babylon came [into Jerusalem] and sat down at the Middle Gate: Nergal-Sharezer ·of the district of Samgar [or Samgar-nebo]; Nebo-Sarsekim, a chief ·officer [or eunuch]; Nergal-Sharezer, ·an important leader [or the Rabmag]; and all the other important officers.

4.verse: When Zedekiah king of Judah and all his soldiers saw them, they ·ran away [fled]. They ·left [went out of] Jerusalem at night and went out ·from [by way of] the king’s garden. They went through the gate that was between the two walls and then headed toward the ·Jordan Valley [Arabah].

5.verse: But the ·Babylonian [Chaldean] army ·chased [pursued] them and ·caught up with [overtook] Zedekiah in the plains of Jericho. They captured him and took him to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, who was at the town of Riblah in the land of Hamath [north of Israel, in Syria]. There Nebuchadnezzar passed ·his sentence [judgment] on Zedekiah.

6.verse: At Riblah the king of Babylon ·killed [slaughtered] Zedekiah’s sons and all the ·important officers [nobles] of Judah ·as Zedekiah watched [before his eyes].

7.verse: Then he ·put out [blinded] Zedekiah’s eyes. He put bronze chains on Zedekiah and took him to Babylon.

8.verse: The ·Babylonians [Chaldeans] ·set fire to [burned with fire] the ·palace [house of the king] and to the houses of the people, and they ·broke [tore] down the walls around Jerusalem.

9.verse: Nebuzaradan, commander of the king’s special guards, took the people left in Jerusalem, those captives who had ·surrendered [deserted; defected; fell] to him earlier, and the rest of the people of Jerusalem, and he ·took them all away [exiled them all] to Babylon.

10.verse: But Nebuzaradan, commander of the guard, left some of the poorest people of Judah behind. They owned nothing, but that day he gave them vineyards and fields.

11.verse: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon had ·given these orders [commanded] about Jeremiah through Nebuzaradan, commander of the guard:

12.verse: “Find Jeremiah and take care of him. Do not ·hurt [do evil to] him, but do for him whatever he asks you.”

13.verse: So Nebuchadnezzar sent these men for Jeremiah: Nebuzaradan, commander of the guards; Nebushazban, a chief ·officer [or eunuch]; Nergal-Sharezer, ·an important leader [or the Rabmag]; and all the other officers of the king of Babylon.

14.verse: They had Jeremiah taken out of the courtyard of the guard. Then they turned him over to Gedaliah son of Ahikam son of Shaphan [the new governor of the Babylonian province of Judah; 40:5], who had orders to take Jeremiah back home. So they took him home, and he stayed among the people left in Judah.

15.verse: While Jeremiah was guarded in the courtyard, the LORD spoke his word to him:

16.verse: “Jeremiah, go and tell Ebed-Melech the Cushite [Ethiopian; 38:7–13] this message: ‘This is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: Very soon I will make my words about this city [Jerusalem] come true ·through [for] ·disaster [evil; trouble], not ·through [for] ·good times [good]. You will see everything come true with your own eyes.

17.verse: But I will ·save [rescue; deliver ] you on that day, Ebed-Melech, says the LORD. You will not be handed over to the people you fear.

18.verse: I will surely ·save [rescue] you [Ebed-Melech]. You will not ·die from [fall by] a sword, but ·you will escape and live [your life will be plunder]. This will happen because you have ·trusted [confidence] in me, says the LORD.’”

1.verse: Jeremiah Is Set Free - The LORD spoke his word to Jeremiah after Nebuzaradan, commander of the guards, had ·set Jeremiah free at the city of [released/sent him from] Ramah. He had found Jeremiah in Ramah bound in ·chains [fetters] with all the ·captives [exiles] from Jerusalem and Judah who were being ·taken away [exiled] to Babylon.

2.verse: When commander ·Nebuzaradan [of the guards] ·found [took] Jeremiah, Nebuzaradan said to him, “The LORD your God announced this ·disaster [evil; trouble] would come to this place.

3.verse: And now the LORD has done everything he ·said [promised] he would do. This ·disaster [evil; trouble] happened because you [the people of Judah] sinned against the LORD and did not ·obey him [listen to his voice].

4.verse: But today I am ·freeing [releasing] you from the ·chains [fetters] on your ·wrists [hands]. If ·you want to [it is good in your eyes], come with me to Babylon, and I will ·take good care of you [set my eyes on you]. But if ·you don’t want to come [it is wrong/evil/bad in your eyes to come with me to Babylon], then ·don’t [fine]. Look, the whole country is open to you. Go wherever ·you wish [it is good and right in your eyes].”

5.verse: Before Jeremiah turned to leave, Nebuzaradan said, “Or go back to Gedaliah son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan. The king of Babylon has ·chosen [appointed] him to be governor over the towns of Judah. Go and ·live [stay] with Gedaliah among the people, or go anywhere ·you want [it is right in your eyes].” Then Nebuzaradan gave Jeremiah some ·food [provisions] and a ·present [gift] and let him go.

6.verse: So Jeremiah went to Gedaliah son of Ahikam at Mizpah [perhaps Tell en-Nasbeh eight miles north of Jerusalem; Judg. 20:1–3; 1 Sam. 7:5–14; 10:17–24] and stayed with him there. He lived among the people who ·were left behind in Judah [remained in the land].

7.verse: The Short Rule of Gedaliah - Some officers and their men from the army of Judah were still out in the open country. They heard that the king of Babylon had ·put [appointed] Gedaliah son of Ahikam ·in charge of the people [governor of those] who ·were left [remained] in the land: the men, women, and children who were the poorest. They were the ones who were not ·taken to Babylon as captives [exiled to Babylon].

8.verse: So these soldiers came to Gedaliah at Mizpah: Ishmael son of Nethaniah, Johanan and Jonathan sons of Kareah, Seraiah son of Tanhumeth, the sons of Ephai the Netophathite, Jaazaniah son of the Maacathite, and their men.

9.verse: Gedaliah son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, ·made a promise [swore] to them, saying, “Do not be afraid to serve the ·Babylonians [Chaldeans]. Stay in the land and serve the king of Babylon. Then everything will go well for you.

10.verse: I myself will live in Mizpah and will ·speak for you [represent you; stand] before the ·Babylonians [Chaldeans] who come to us here. Harvest the wine, the summer fruit, and the oil, and put what you harvest in your storage jars. Live in the towns you control.”

11.verse: The ·Jews [Judeans] in Moab, ·Ammon [the sons of Ammon], Edom, and other countries also heard that the king of Babylon had left a ·few Jews alive in the land [remnant in Judea]. And they heard the king of Babylon had ·chosen [appointed] Gedaliah as governor over them. (Gedaliah was the son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan.)

12.verse: When the people of Judah heard this news, they came back to Judah from all the countries where they had been scattered. They came to Gedaliah at Mizpah and gathered a large harvest of wine and summer fruit.

13.verse: Johanan son of Kareah and all the army officers of Judah still in the open country came to Gedaliah at Mizpah.

14.verse: They said to him, “Don’t you know that Baalis king of the ·Ammonite people [sons of Ammon] wants you dead? He has sent Ishmael son of Nethaniah to ·kill you [strike your life].” But Gedaliah son of Ahikam ·did [or would] not believe them.

15.verse: Then Johanan son of Kareah spoke to Gedaliah in ·private [secret] at Mizpah. He said, “Let me go and ·kill [strike] Ishmael son of Nethaniah. No one will know anything about it. ·We should not let Ishmael [Why should he…?] ·kill you [strike your life]. Then all ·the Jews [Judah] gathered around you would be scattered to different countries again, and the ·few people of Judah who are left alive [the remnant of Judah] would ·be lost [perish].”

16.verse: But Gedaliah son of Ahikam said to Johanan son of Kareah, “Do not ·kill Ishmael [do this thing]! The things you are saying about Ishmael are ·not true [false; lies].”

1.verse: In the seventh month Ishmael son of Nethaniah and ten of his men came to Gedaliah son of Ahikam [the Babylonian appointed governor] at Mizpah [40:6]. (Nethaniah was the son of Elishama.) Now Ishmael was a member of the ·king’s [royal] family and had been one of the officers of the king of Judah. While they were eating ·a meal with Gedaliah [bread together] at Mizpah,

2.verse: Ishmael and his ten men got up and killed Gedaliah son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, with a sword. (Gedaliah was the man the king of Babylon had ·chosen [appointed] as governor over Judah.)

3.verse: Ishmael also killed all the ·Jews [Judeans] and the ·Babylonian [Chaldean] soldiers who were there with Gedaliah at Mizpah.

4.verse: The day after Gedaliah was murdered, before anyone knew about it,

5.verse: eighty men came to Mizpah bringing ·grain [gift; tribute] offerings [Lev. 2:1] and incense to the ·Temple [house] of the LORD. Those men from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria [important centers in northern Israel] had shaved off their beards, torn their clothes, and ·cut [gashed] themselves [mourning rituals].

6.verse: Ishmael son of Nethaniah went out from Mizpah to meet them, crying as he walked. When he ·met [encountered] them, he said, “Come with me to meet Gedaliah son of Ahikam.”

7.verse: So they went into Mizpah. Then Ishmael son of Nethaniah and his men ·killed [slaughtered] seventy of them and threw the bodies into a deep ·well [cistern; pit].

8.verse: But the ten men who were ·left alive [still found] said to Ishmael, “Don’t kill us! We have stores of wheat and barley and oil and honey that we have hidden in a field.” So ·Ishmael let them live [he stopped] and did not kill them with the others.

9.verse: Now the ·well [cistern; pit] where he had thrown all the bodies had been made by King Asa [ruled 913–873 BC] as a part of his defenses against Baasha king of Israel [ruled 900–877 BC; 1 Kin. 15:9–24; 15:33—16:7]. But Ishmael son of Nethaniah put dead bodies in it until it was full.

10.verse: Ishmael captured all the other people in Mizpah: the king’s daughters and all the other people who ·were left [remained] there. They were the ones whom Nebuzaradan commander of the guard had ·chosen Gedaliah son of Ahikam to take care of [appointed Gedaliah son of Ahikam as governor over]. So Ishmael son of Nethaniah captured those people, and he started to cross over to the country of the ·Ammonites [sons of Ammon].

11.verse: Johanan son of Kareah [40:13–14] and all his army officers with him heard about all the ·evil things [crimes] Ishmael son of Nethaniah had done.

12.verse: So they took their men and went to fight Ishmael son of Nethaniah and ·caught [found] him near the ·big pool of water [many waters] at Gibeon [southwest of Mizpah; 2 Sam. 2:8–17].

13.verse: When ·the captives Ishmael had taken [all the people who were with Ishmael] saw Johanan and the army officers, they were glad.

14.verse: So all the people Ishmael had taken captive from Mizpah turned around and ran to Johanan son of Kareah.

15.verse: But Ishmael son of Nethaniah and eight of his men escaped from Johanan and ran away to the ·Ammonites [sons of Ammon].

16.verse: So Johanan son of Kareah and all his army officers ·saved [took] the captives that Ishmael son of Nethaniah had taken from Mizpah after he ·murdered [struck] Gedaliah son of Ahikam. Among those left alive were soldiers, women, children, and ·palace officers [or eunuchs]. And Johanan brought them back from the town of Gibeon.

17.verse: The Escape to Egypt - Johanan and the other army officers were afraid of the ·Babylonians [Chaldeans]. Since the king of Babylon had chosen Gedaliah son of Ahikam to be governor of Judah but Ishmael son of Nethaniah had ·murdered [struck] him, Johanan was afraid that the Babylonians would be angry. So they decided to run away to Egypt. On the way they stayed at Geruth Kimham, near the town of Bethlehem.

18.verse: The Escape to Egypt - Johanan and the other army officers were afraid of the ·Babylonians [Chaldeans]. Since the king of Babylon had chosen Gedaliah son of Ahikam to be governor of Judah but Ishmael son of Nethaniah had ·murdered [struck] him, Johanan was afraid that the Babylonians would be angry. So they decided to run away to Egypt. On the way they stayed at Geruth Kimham, near the town of Bethlehem.

1.verse: While there, Johanan son of Kareah and Jezaniah [or Azariah; 43:2] son of Hoshaiah ·went to [approached] Jeremiah the prophet. All the army officers and all the people, from the least important to the greatest, went along, too.

2.verse: They said to him, “Jeremiah, ·please listen to what we ask [let our pleas for help/supplications fall before you]. Pray to the LORD your God for all ·the people left alive from the family of Judah [this remnant]. At one time there were many of us, but ·you can see that [as your eyes can see] there are few of us now.

3.verse: So pray that the LORD your God will tell us ·where we should go [the path on which we should go] and what we should do.”

4.verse: Then Jeremiah the prophet answered, “I ·understand what you want me to do [hear]. I will pray to the LORD your God ·as you have asked [according to your works]. I will tell you ·everything he says [all his answers] and not ·hide [keep back] anything from you.”

5.verse: Then the people said to Jeremiah, “May the LORD be a true and ·loyal [faithful] witness against us if we don’t do everything the LORD your God sends you to tell us.

6.verse: ·It does not matter if we like the message or not [Whether good or bad…]. We will ·obey [listen to] the LORD our God, to whom we are sending you. We will ·obey [listen to] what he says so good things will happen to us.”

7.verse: Ten days later the LORD spoke his word to Jeremiah.

8.verse: Then Jeremiah called for Johanan son of Kareah, the army officers with him, and all the other people, from the least important to the greatest.

9.verse: Jeremiah said to them, “You sent me to ·ask the LORD for what you wanted [make your supplications/fall before him]. This is what the God of Israel says:

10.verse: ‘If you will stay in this land [Judah], I will build you up and not tear you down. I will plant you and not ·pull [tear] you up [1:10], because I am ·sad [sorry] about the ·disaster [evil; trouble] I ·brought on [did to] you.

11.verse: Now you fear the king of Babylon, but don’t be afraid of him. Don’t be afraid of him,’ says the LORD, ‘because I am with you. I will save you and ·rescue [protect] you from his ·power [hand].

12.verse: I will be ·kind [compassionate; merciful] to you, and he will also treat you with ·mercy [kindness; compassion] and ·let you stay [restore you] in your land.’

13.verse: “But if you say, ‘We will not stay in this land [Judah],’ you will ·disobey [not listen to the voice of] the LORD your God.

14.verse: Or you might say, ‘No, we will go and live in Egypt. There we will not see war, or hear the trumpets of ·war [battle], or ·be hungry [famine].’

15.verse: If you say that, listen to the message of the LORD, ·you who are left alive from [remnant of] Judah. This is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: ‘If you ·make up your mind [are determined] to go and live in Egypt, these things will happen:

16.verse: ·You are afraid of war, but it will find you [The sword you fear will overtake you there,] in the land of Egypt. And ·you are worried about hunger, but it will follow you into [the famine you dread will cling after you there in] Egypt, and you will die there.

17.verse: Everyone who ·goes to live in [sets their face to go to] Egypt will die ·in war [by sword] or from ·hunger [famine] or ·terrible disease [plague; pestilence]. ·No one who goes to Egypt will live; no one will escape [There will be no remnant or survivor from] the ·terrible things [harm; evil] I will bring to them.’

18.verse: “This is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: ‘I ·showed [poured out] my anger against the people of Jerusalem. In the same way I will ·show [pour out] my anger against you when you go to Egypt. Other nations will speak evil of you. People will be ·shocked [horrified] by what will happen to you. You will become a curse word, and people will ·insult [ridicule] you. And you will never see this place [Judah] again.’

19.verse: “·You who are left alive in [Remnant of] Judah, the LORD has told you, ‘Don’t go to Egypt.’ Be sure you ·understand [know] this; I warn you today

20.verse: that you ·are making a mistake that will cause your deaths [made a fatal mistake; have erred with your life]. You sent me to the LORD your God, saying, ‘Pray to the LORD our God for us. Tell us everything the LORD our God says, and we will do it.’

21.verse: So today I have ·told [proclaimed to] you, but you have not ·obeyed [listened to the voice of] the LORD your God in all that he sent me to tell you.

22.verse: So now be sure you ·understand [know] this: You want to go to live in Egypt, but you will die there by ·war [sword], ·hunger [famine], or ·terrible diseases [plague; pestilence].”

1.verse: So Jeremiah finished telling the people the message from the LORD their God; he told them everything the LORD their God had sent him to tell them.

2.verse: Azariah son of Hoshaiah [42:1], Johanan son of Kareah, and some other men were ·too proud [arrogant]. They said to Jeremiah, “You are lying! The LORD our God did not send you to say, ‘You must not go to Egypt to ·live [sojourn; wander] there.’

3.verse: Baruch son of Neriah [Jeremiah’s assistant; chs. 35; 45] is causing you to be against us. He wants you to hand us over to the ·Babylonians [Chaldeans] so they can kill us or ·capture us and take [exile] us to Babylon.”

4.verse: So Johanan, the army officers, and all the people ·disobeyed the LORD’s command [did not listen to the voice of the LORD] to stay in Judah.

5.verse: But Johanan son of Kareah and the army officers ·led away [took] ·those who were left alive from [the remnant of] Judah. They were the people who had ·run away from the Babylonians [been driven] to other countries but then had ·come back to live in [returned to] Judah.

6.verse: They ·led away [took] the men, women, and children, and the king’s daughters. Nebuzaradan commander of the guard had ·put Gedaliah son of Ahikam son of Shaphan in charge of those people [left with Gedaliah son of Ahikam son of Shaphan; who had been appointed governor]. Johanan also took Jeremiah the prophet and Baruch son of Neriah.

7.verse: These people did not listen to the voice of the LORD. So they all went to Egypt to the city of Tahpanhes [in the eastern region of the Nile Delta].

8.verse: In Tahpanhes the LORD spoke his word to Jeremiah:

9.verse: “Take some large stones. Bury them in the clay in the brick pavement in front of the ·king of Egypt’s palace [house of Pharaoh] in Tahpanhes. Do this ·while the Jews are watching you [before the eyes of the Judeans].

10.verse: Then say to them, ‘This is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: I will soon send for my servant, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon. I will set his throne over these stones I have buried, and he will spread his ·covering for shade [canopy] above them.

11.verse: He will come here and ·attack [strike] Egypt. He will bring death to those who are supposed to die. He will make ·prisoners [exiles] of those who are to be ·taken captive [exiled], and he will bring ·war to [to the sword] those who are to be killed with a sword.

12.verse: Nebuchadnezzar will ·set [kindle a] fire to the ·temples [houses] of the gods of Egypt and burn them. And he will take ·the idols [them] away as captives. As a shepherd ·wraps himself in [or picks lice from] his clothes, so Nebuchadnezzar ·will wrap Egypt around him [or picks the land of Egypt clean]. Then he will safely leave Egypt.

13.verse: He will ·destroy [break] the stone pillars in the ·temple [house] of the sun god in Egypt, and he will burn ·down [with fire] the ·temples [houses] of the gods of Egypt.’”

1.verse: Disaster in Egypt - Jeremiah received a message from the LORD for all the ·Jews [Judeans] living in Egypt—in the cities of Migdol [a city in the Nile Delta], Tahpanhes [43:7], Memphis [a capital city in central Egypt], and in ·southern Egypt [the land of Pathros]. This was the message:

2.verse: “The LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: You saw all the ·terrible things [disasters; evil; troubles] I brought on Jerusalem and the towns of Judah, which are ruins today with no one living in them.

3.verse: It is because the people who lived there did evil. They made me angry by burning incense and ·worshiping [serving] other gods that neither they nor you nor your ·ancestors [fathers] ever knew.

4.verse: I sent all my servants, the prophets, to you again and again. By them I said to you, ‘Don’t do this ·terrible [abominable] thing that I hate.’

5.verse: But they did not listen or ·pay attention [incline their ear]. They did not ·stop doing [turn back from] evil things and burning incense to other gods.

6.verse: So I showed my great anger against them. I poured out my anger in the towns of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem so they are only ruins and ·piles of stones [a desolation] today.

7.verse: “Now the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts], the God of Israel, says: Why are you doing such great ·harm [damage; evil] to yourselves? You are cutting off the men and women, children and ·babies [suckling infants] from the ·family [midst] of Judah, leaving yourselves without ·anyone from the family of Judah [a remnant].

8.verse: Why do you want to make me angry by ·making idols [the work of your hands]? Why do you ·burn incense [make offerings] to the gods of Egypt, where you have come to ·live [sojourn; wander]? You will ·destroy [cut off] yourselves. Other nations will ·speak evil of [curse] you and ·make fun of [reproach] you.

44.verse: I will punish the god Bel [another name for Marduk, the chief god of Babylon] in Babylon. I will make him spit out what he has swallowed. Nations will no longer ·come [stream] to Babylon; even the wall around the city will fall.

45.verse: “Come out of it [Babylon], my people! ·Run for [Escape with] your lives! ·Run [Escape] from the LORD’s great anger.

46.verse: Don’t lose ·courage [heart]; rumors will spread through the land, but don’t be afraid. One rumor comes this year, and another comes the next year. There will be rumors of ·terrible fighting [violence] in the country, of rulers fighting against rulers.

47.verse: The ·time will surely come [days are coming] when I will punish the idols of Babylon, and the whole land will be disgraced. There will be many ·dead people [corpses] ·lying all around [falling in its midst].

48.verse: Then heaven and earth and all that is in them will shout for joy about Babylon. They will shout because the army comes from the north [Persia and its allies] to destroy Babylon,” says the LORD.

49.verse: “Babylon must fall, because ·she killed people from [of the corpses of] Israel. ·She killed people from everywhere on […and the corpses of all the] earth.

50.verse: You who have escaped being killed with swords, ·leave Babylon [go; flee; depart]! Don’t wait! Remember the LORD in the faraway land and ·think about Jerusalem [let Jerusalem come up in your heart/mind].”

51.verse: “We people of Judah are disgraced, because we have been ·insulted [reproached]. ·We have been shamed [Shame/Humiliation covers our face], because strangers have gone into the holy places of the LORD’s Temple [house]!”

52.verse: So the LORD says, “The ·time is [days are] coming soon when I will punish the idols of Babylon. Wounded people will ·cry with pain [groan] all over that land.

53.verse: Even if Babylon grows until she touches the ·sky [heavens], and even if she ·makes her highest cities strong [fortifies her lofty stronghold], I will send people to destroy her,” says the LORD.

54.verse: “Sounds of people crying are heard in Babylon. Sounds of ·people destroying things [great destruction] are heard in the land of the Babylonians.

55.verse: The LORD is destroying Babylon and making the loud sounds of the city become silent. Enemies come roaring in like ocean waves. The roar of their voices is heard all around.

56.verse: ·The army has come to destroy [Destroyers have come to] Babylon. Her soldiers have been captured, and their bows are broken, because the LORD is a God who punishes people for the evil they do. He ·gives them the full punishment they deserve [repays them in full].

57.verse: I will make Babylon’s rulers and wise men drunk [with the cup of God’s wrath; 25:15–38], and her governors, officers, and soldiers, too. Then they will sleep forever and never wake up [v. 39],” says the King, whose name is the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts].

58.verse: This is what the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts] says: “Babylon’s ·thick [broad] wall will be completely ·pulled down [leveled] and her high gates burned with fire. The people will ·work hard [weary themselves], but it won’t help; their work will only become fuel for the flames!”

59.verse: A Message to Babylon - This is the message that Jeremiah the prophet gave to the officer Seraiah son of Neriah, who was the son of Mahseiah [probably Baruch’s brother; 32:12]. Seraiah went to Babylon with Zedekiah king of Judah in the fourth year Zedekiah was king of Judah [593 BC]. ·His duty was to arrange the king’s food and housing on the trip [He was the quartermaster].

60.verse: Jeremiah had written on a scroll all the ·terrible [disastrous; evil] things that would happen to Babylon, all these words about Babylon.

61.verse: Jeremiah said to Seraiah, “As soon as you come to Babylon, be sure to read this message so all the people can hear you.

62.verse: Then say, ‘LORD, you have said that you will ·destroy [cut off] this place so that no people or animals will live in it. It will be an ·empty ruin [desolation] forever.’

63.verse: After you finish reading this scroll, tie a stone to it and throw it into the Euphrates River.

64.verse: Then say, ‘In the same way Babylon will sink and will not rise again because of the ·terrible [disastrous; evil] things I will make happen here. Her people will fall.’” ·The words of Jeremiah end here [Thus far are the words of Jeremiah].

1.verse: The Fall of Jerusalem - Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king, and he was king in Jerusalem for eleven years [from 597–586 BC]. His mother’s name was Hamutal daughter of Jeremiah [not the prophet], and she was from Libnah.

2.verse: Zedekiah did ·what the LORD said was wrong [evil in the eyes of the LORD], just as Jehoiakim [his brother who ruled from 609–597 BC] had done.

3.verse: All this happened in Jerusalem and Judah because the LORD was angry with them. Finally, he threw them out of his presence. Zedekiah ·turned [rebelled] against the king of Babylon.

4.verse: Then Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon marched against Jerusalem with his whole army. They made a camp around the city and built ·devices [siege towers] all around the city walls to attack it. This happened on Zedekiah’s ninth year, tenth month, and tenth day as king [January 15, 588].

5.verse: And the city was under ·attack [siege] until Zedekiah’s eleventh year as king [586 BC].

6.verse: By the ninth day of the fourth month [July 18], the ·hunger [famine] was ·terrible [severe] in the city; there was no food for the people to eat.

7.verse: Then the city wall was ·broken through [breeched], and the whole army [of Judah] ·ran away [fled] at night. They left the city through the gate between the two walls by the king’s garden. Even though the ·Babylonians [Chaldeans] were surrounding the city, Zedekiah and his men headed toward the ·Jordan Valley [Arabah].

8.verse: But the ·Babylonian [Chaldean] army chased King Zedekiah and caught him in the ·plains [Arabah] of Jericho. All of his army was scattered from him.

9.verse: So the Babylonians ·captured [seized] Zedekiah and took him to the king of Babylon at the town of Riblah in the land of Hamath. There he ·passed sentence on [judged] Zedekiah.

10.verse: At Riblah the king of Babylon ·killed [slaughtered] Zedekiah’s sons ·as he watched [before his eyes]. The king also ·killed [slaughtered] all the officers of Judah.

11.verse: Then he ·put out Zedekiah’s eyes [blinded the eyes of Zedekiah], and put bronze chains on him, and took him to Babylon. And the king kept Zedekiah in prison there until the day he died.

12.verse: Nebuzaradan, commander of the king’s special guards and servant of the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem on the tenth day of the fifth month. This was in Nebuchadnezzar’s nineteenth year as king of Babylon [August 17, 586 BC].

13.verse: Nebuzaradan set fire to the ·Temple [house] of the LORD, the ·palace [house of the king], and all the houses of Jerusalem; every ·important building [great/big house] was burned.

14.verse: The whole ·Babylonian [Chaldean] army, led by the commander of the king’s special guards, ·broke down [demolished] all the walls around Jerusalem.

15.verse: Nebuzaradan, the commander of the king’s special guards, took captive some of the poorest people, those who ·were left [remained] in Jerusalem, those who had ·surrendered [deserted; defected] to the king of Babylon, and the ·skilled craftsmen [artisans] who were left in Jerusalem.

16.verse: But Nebuzaradan left behind some of the poorest people of the land to take care of the vineyards and fields.

17.verse: The ·Babylonians [Chaldeans] broke into pieces the bronze pillars [1 Kin. 7:15–22], the bronze stands [1 Kin. 7:27], and the large bronze ·bowl [basin], called the Sea [1 Kin. 7:23–26], which were in the ·Temple [house] of the LORD. Then they carried all the bronze pieces to Babylon.

18.verse: They also took the pots, shovels, ·wick trimmers [snuffers], bowls, dishes, and all the bronze objects used to serve in the Temple.

19.verse: The commander of the king’s special guards took away bowls, ·pans for carrying hot coals [firepans], large bowls, pots, lampstands, pans, and bowls used for drink offerings. He took everything that was made of pure gold or silver.

20.verse: There was so much bronze that it could not be weighed: two pillars, the large bronze bowl called the Sea with the twelve bronze bulls under it, and the movable stands, which King Solomon had made for the Temple of the LORD.

21.verse: Each of the pillars was about ·twenty-seven feet [eighteen cubits] high, eighteen feet [twelve cubits] around, and hollow inside. The wall of each pillar was ·three inches [four fingers] thick.

22.verse: The bronze capital on top of the one pillar was about ·seven and one-half feet [five cubits] high. It was decorated with ·a net design [network; latticework] and bronze pomegranates all around it. The other pillar also had pomegranates and was like the first pillar.

23.verse: There were ninety-six pomegranates on the sides of the pillars. There was a total of a hundred pomegranates above the ·net design [network; latticework].

24.verse: The commander of the king’s special guards took as prisoners Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah the priest next in rank, and the three doorkeepers.

25.verse: He also took from the city the officer in charge of the soldiers, seven people ·who advised the king [of the king’s council], the ·royal secretary [scribe] who selected people for the army, and sixty other men from Judah who were in the city when it fell.

26.verse: Nebuzaradan, the commander, took these people and brought them to the king of Babylon at the town of Riblah.

27.verse: There at Riblah, in the land of Hamath, the king had them killed. So the people of Judah were led away from their country as ·captives [exiles].

28.verse: This is the number of the people Nebuchadnezzar took away as ·captives [exiles]: in the seventh year [597 BC], 3,023 ·Jews [Judeans];

29.verse: in Nebuchadnezzar’s eighteenth year [586 BC], 832 people from Jerusalem;

30.verse: in Nebuchadnezzar’s twenty-third year [582 BC], Nebuzaradan, commander of the king’s special guards, took 745 ·Jews [Judeans] as ·captives [exiles]. In all 4,600 people were ·taken captive [exiled].

31.verse: Jehoiachin Is Set Free - Jehoiachin king of Judah was in prison in Babylon for thirty-seven years. The year Evil-Merodach became king of Babylon [a son of Nebuchadnezzar, he ruled 562–560 BC] he let Jehoiachin king of Judah out of ·prison [house of confinement]. He set Jehoiachin free on the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month [March 31, 561 BC].

32.verse: Evil-Merodach spoke kindly to Jehoiachin and gave him a seat of honor above the seats of the other kings who were with him in Babylon [he honored him above other defeated vassal kings].

33.verse: So Jehoiachin put away his prison clothes, and for the rest of his life, he ate at the king’s table.

34.verse: Every day the king of Babylon gave Jehoiachin an allowance. This lasted as long as he lived, until the day Jehoiachin died.
